captions.text:
Bill Gates: Right now, the disease we're focused
on is polio. The world finished smallpox officially

in 1980 -- was when they signed the certificate.
Polio we hope to get done, get our certificate

by 2018, and then if, you know, the credibility,
the energy from that will allow us to take

the new tools we'll have then and go after
a malaria plan.

John Green: I also wanted to ask you about
the P6, the keg of life, as you called it?

Bill: Well, often something will be invented
and people won't realize that it has a use

in poor countries. You can make these thermoses
that leak, the heat leaks in very, very slowly,

you know, that was invented like 15 years
ago, and nobody thought, oh, well, hey, we

can help poor countries with this cold chain
problem, because for them, they don't have

electricity, even getting kerosene and propane
is expensive, it's unreliable. We built the

first one about a year ago, and now they're
out in the field. You don't need that in the

United States, because our refrigerators are
very reliable, you know, we assume we have

24 hour electricity, we assume patients can
easily get to the doctor, so the matching

of the good ideas with the big important needs,
that's a pretty imperfect process.

John: You seen very careful, actually, not
to talk about giving money away and instead,

have repeatedly said that you're giving money
back.

Bill: Well, capitalism is a weird system.
I mean, it's a fantastic system; it provides

an incentive for people to work, but it means
that somebody who, by having certain skills

and creating a company at the right time,
can end up with a mind-blowing amount of resources.

So Melinda and I, my wife, talked about this,
where's the greatest injustice, where can

a dollar save a life or avoid malnutrition?
In studying that, that's why we ended up saying,

boy, in poor countries, you can have this
huge impact.

John: I wonder if you can kind of talk about
where you see the healthcare system of Ethiopia

in five or ten years, and when you see that
making a sort of overall economic impact in
the health of the country.

Bill: Well, the last ten years, they've gotten
their childhood death rate down from over

15% down to about 8%, and they should be able
to get it down below 2%; the US is below 1%.

Also, the malnourishment, which you see through
stunting, still pretty high here. And by finding

the children that aren't growing and getting
nutritious foods out and proving agriculture

productivity, that'll be able to virtually
eliminate malnutrition. That means Ethiopia

will, and this is their stated goal, be a
middle-income country by 2025. They absolutely

can get there, and the progress is very exciting.
Health is such an enabling piece, and the

country's really pulling together; the system
is well-designed; you know, the donors, like

ourselves, are here and trying to think, okay,
what tools are missing? So it's a very positive

story, uh, one that I don't think most people
know about.

title: Bill Gates and John Green Discuss Progress

comments.author: beezerboy94

comments.text:
Much respect for him and people like him. So rare to see a person in his 
position try to make a positive difference as much as he does. However, it 
is a shame that all his efforts, in the end, will not improve the overall 
situation of the people in Ethiopia or the world as a whole. Please do not 
get me wrong. Reducing child mortality is AWESOME, and the concept of 
trying to eradicate an entire disease is magnificent. It will go a long way 
to reducing suffering and improving the lives of many.

However, Ethiopia's population has increased fivefold in the last fifty 
years. Where in 1950 the population was a mere 18 million, now it is 87 
million. Projections show that at the current rate, it will host several 
hundred million people within 50 years. This is an economic and 
humanitarian disaster. You can throw all the development aid, medicine, 
education and volunteer organizations in the world at this country, but it, 
and countries like it, will continue to be a horrorshow of suffering and 
insufficience. In fact many of these strategies, such as food aid, will 
only worsen the situation. It's a horrible thing to say, but as long as 
these people don't get their demographics under control, any of our efforts 
in helping them will inevitably be futile.

You can't just continue having 5 children per mother when you couldn't even 
feed, house and educate 2 of them. It's simple logic. It is unfair and 
unrealistic to expect the developed world to take on such a responsibility. 
At some point, personal responsibility has to be taken. In western 
countries, "native" populations have largely stabilized, in many cases even 
started to shrink. This is a good thing - fewer people means better living 
conditions and less pressure on the ecology of this planet. However, 
constant migrant streams from poorer countries mean that our overall 
population is still increasing.

We don't need another three billion people on this planet. Regardless of 
where they're from.﻿

I would love to see you/nerdfighteria work with Free The Children, an 
organization I had the privilege to volunteer with over the summer. It 
operates on five pillars for change: education, clean water and sanitation, 
health, alternative income and livelihood, and agriculture and food safety. 
This organization is very dear to my heart and offers opportunities for 
nerdfighteria to help on many levels.﻿

comments.author: Fritz Bause

comments.text:
I want to commend you on what you HAVE done, what you CONTINUE to do and 
what you do without even realizing it. By doing what you do, you encourage 
me in my job (Teaching High School Equivalency to Indians on the 
Reservation)- encourage me to not see ALL the problems as insurmountable- 
just a series of small problems (like when Bill talks about just solving 
Polio and then move on to Malaria) - that when tackled, become less 
problems. You remind me to have fun, remind me to be myself, and that THAT 
is ENOUGH and always will be. You remind me that the world is a quirky, 
strange, unfair place but that it bends toward justice, towards beautiful, 
towards amazing.

and you did all that without even trying- just doing what you do. Thanks.﻿

comments.text:
Bill Gates and +John Green discuss progress in Ethiopia, designing 
technologies for poor countries, improving childhood nutrition, the 
blessings and limitations of capitalism, and Ethiopia's road to achieving 
middle-income status by 2025. Many thanks to @brandonbrungard for making 
these videos! 

Follow him on Twitter here:
https://www.twitter.com/BrandonBrungard﻿
